AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Nashville Sound: Delta Blues Shot With Rock Riffs
DOC.TEXT: It's called ``Snake music'' _ Delta blues shot through with rock riffs and punchy drumming. And if the drummer gives the beat a soulful touch, it's because he once played for Aretha Franklin. The band is the Snakes, who have released their self-titled debut album amid comparisons to the Fabulous Thunderbirds. The group, composed of veteran recording session musicians, plays a tight mix of original and reworked blues and rock 'n' roll tunes. The connection to the Fabulous Thunderbirds doesn't end with the sound. Snakes pianist Wally Wilson co-wrote the Thunderbirds' hit ``Powerful Stuff,'' featured in the soundtrack for the movie ``Cocktail.'' Wilson, who is also a veteran country music and rock songwriter, says the band didn't plan for the new LP to sound like the Thunderbirds, but he likes the comparison. The album contains Snakes' versions of two songs by the late blues legends Robert Johnson and Bukka White: Johnson's ``32-20'' and White's ``Aberdeen,'' a marriage of acoustic Delta blues and hard-edged rock. It also features ``Walkaway,'' heard on the soundtrack for the movie ``Major League.'' Perhaps the most unusual tune on the LP is ``Pay Bo Diddley,'' a humorous but scathing look at how the famous rock 'n' roll pioneer was cheated out of royalties by smooth talking record company executives. Wilson persuaded Diddley to come to Nashville to sing and play guitar on the cut. ``When we brought him up here to do the session, he loved it,'' Wilson said. ``It was his song. He was king for a day.'' Wilson adds that he had to wire half of the cash fee for the session to Diddley at his Florida home before the performer would come to Nashville. He was paid the other half, in cash of course, once he arrived. Recording an album wasn't on the minds of founding members Wilson and guitarist-vocalist Mike Henderson when they met and began playing the blues in Nashville. ``We decided we would get the Mike and Wally show together and play Holiday Inns and places like that,'' Wilson joked. ``We got a four-piece band together to play Monday nights at the Bluebird (Cafe),'' he said. The Bluebird is known as a breeding ground for new talent and many artists have been signed to their first recording contracts after appearing there. At first the Snakes played to an audience consisting mainly of waitresses, but in time college students and members of the music industry became fans. ``Pretty soon ... it was jam packed in there,'' Wilson said. He credits that success to the combination of original members Henderson, bassist Glenn Worf and drummer Bill Swartz. But as the group's sound began to evolve from straight blues to blues-rock, guitarist Kenny Greenberg was added and Swartz was replaced by veteran rhythm and blues drummer James Stroud. The lineup started playing more clubs in Nashville and attracted the attention of Curb Records executive Dick Whitehouse, who signed them to a record deal. The effortless dovetailing of the musicians' styles is the reason for their success, Wilson says. ``Kenny is an incredible rock guitarist. When he came here (from Louisville, Ky.,) he was going to play country. That lasted about two days,'' said Wilson, who migrated to Nashville from Dallas and started as a janitor at a music publishing company. ``Kenny is the leading guy in this part of the South for playing rock 'n' roll. He has been featured in Guitar Player magazine. He's done a lot of album work.'' Wilson characterizes Worf as the best musician in the band. ``Glenn is an incredible bass player. He is very musical. He could be a jazz musician.'' Stroud also is a record producer and has drummed for such greats as Aretha Franklin. Henderson grew up listening to the blues. He usually sings and plays the harmonica wearing an old Esso service station attendant's shirt and a battered straw cowboy hat. ``He is the strangest guy I've ever met. All of his clothes are second hand,'' Wilson said. ``He thinks it's ridiculous for people to pay more than $20 for an article of clothing. If you see him in a suit, it will be a $10 suit.''
